Evaluation_Questions: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?
Comments_Questions: How well was the course organized?
How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
How did the supplementary materials (files, videos, recordings, etc.) for the course enhance your experience of it?
The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
The course goals were clearly presented.
The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
The grading criteria was clearly explained.
The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
I would recommend this instructor to other students.
How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
How would you rate the overall usefulness of discussion sections for this class?
Was enough time devoted to discussion sections?
Did you attend all the discussions?
Comments_List: It was hard at times to follow the presentations because they would go really fast. For instance we did both Chinese Theater and Japanese Theater in one week and it felt like a lot of information to unpack from two very distinct cultures in two short days. I often found myself feeling lost.

The only time I thought the organization of the course did not make sense was when we were watching video lectures, going to live lectures, and going to discussion groups as the live lectures never really found the right mixture between redundant information and new information. The week it worked best was when the live lecture was less scripted and more of a class-wide discussion group / seminar style course. Paul introduced some new information (Native American practices) in the class in order to emphasize the lessons learned through the video lectures and tie it in to another culture (which was absolutely fascinating).
I think the course was very well organized but it moved so fast that sometimes I felt completely lost in an overwhelming amount of info.
Some powerpoints never finished, lectures left little room for in class discovery or discussion.
One if not THE most rigid course outlines and syllabuses of my YSD experience to date. Seemingly the most traditional academic course within at least my YSD curriculum.
There was obviously a lot of care and consideration put into how the course was curated. However, I think a lot of us are still hungry for more time spent in non-western theatrical practices.

It moved way, way, way too fast and lacked passion in its approach. It was a class of busy work and I wish it would've been taught by someone with a passion for people and experiences as opposed to how time has passed and who did what when.
A little confusing to jump from place to place, but probably inevitable based on material covered.
very well laid out, we knew what was going to be talked about, and for how long.

Canvas was used heavily to organize class material. It is a great resource for this class, but was not organized in a way that was helpful. You had to search through a variety of folders to find the information necessary for the reading or for class. The path was often different. Organizing material in chronological order would be very helpful.
Great organization.
n/a

My Teaching Assistant didn't really put an effort into the discussion section of the class. While my peers in different discussion groups had the chance to unpack the lectures during their discussions, my section would spend a lot of time diverting away from the topics at hand and there felt to be very little organization and direction. In turn, instead of spending the time for discussion trying to clear up any confusions from the lectures, whenever we'd ask questions, the answer that seemed to be repeated constantly was "it's all in the powerpoints". It wasn't all in the powerpoints.

After the midterm, my group discussed with Ilya what we would like to see from him in future group discussions and so things did improve, but prior to the midterm our discussion group really struggled. There was almost no link between lectures, discussion questions, or the discussion group sessions at all. Ilya left a lot of the guidance of the session to us, and he played more of a passive moderator just to keep discussion going when things fizzled. It would have been very helpful / welcomed to have a lesson put together that would help us soak in a bit of the information presented within the live lecture and allow us to comment / ask questions about the materials. Which is what we started to move towards as the semester progressed, but still had some work to do in order to have that scenario really play out.
Having a discussion section is helpful, however I am not engaged during lecture periods and find it difficult to concentrate.

I loved my discussion section! But in terms of in class discussion, I felt that Professor Walsh left no time for us to speak and never seemed to really try to. There was no place made for us to ask questions during lecture or after.

Really enjoyed the early part of the semester where video lectures happened on Tuesday, Paul gave lecture to reinforce on Thursday and seemed to have more time for questions those weeks than when he lectured on both days in the latter part of the semester. The time to ask questions and have Paul move in other directions with the material on those Thursday's was very engaging.
We were instructed in lecture time and we got our points talking in discussion time. The discussion wasn't guided well and it wasn't fun.
I felt as though, with few exceptions, most of the information came from Instruction. Discussion was poorly organized and not helpful.

It was good because we broke out into smaller groups, but I wish that Paul engaged with us more in class. He was so focused on reading the slides that he couldn't even see when people raised their hands to ask a question.
Discussions in the small groups were sometimes great, and other times detrimental.  The instruction in the lectures was just that, only lecturing with a few minutes of questions at the end.

The section leader did an excellent job of leading group discussion that kept me engaged even on days where my mind wanted to be elsewhere. Paul's lectures were very informative but the pace was a bit too fast. It was easy to get lost or lose information if I was trying to take notes. I found I enjoyed the lectures more if I did not attempt notes. The vast amount of information that each lecture went over made little time for discussion.

There has clearly been lots of thought and refinement in the building of this course. I thought it was very effective for the vast amount of information that was covered. I really enjoyed my discussion group and it was invaluable in helping connect all the information together.
The lab portion of the class was not well organized and our discussions were not useful. It would be more helpful to discuss the play that we just read reflecting on the lecture from that.

The lecture portions where rapid fire, with little time for engagement with the instructor at the end. The discussion groups were more productive for me than the lectures, there was adequate time and guidance to explore the material we were presented. I ended up almost exclusively taking notes in the discussion groups as there was barely time in the lecture to even look away from the presentation.

I wish the small groups prepped us more for the exam.  It was hit or miss.  Sometimes the instructor would really prep us, and sometimes we would talk about the play alone.  I wish there was more context.

The inclusion of the discussion groups definitely aids this lack of in-class-discussion. I understand that the breadth of material makes it near impossible to offer time for in-class discussion, though. So, I am thankful for the discussion groups!

Since the class was a lecture format it didn't leave much room for investigation and exploration. I felt like Paul was just talking at me and reading from a script. The best part of the course was the discussion group which moved at a slower more interactive pace.

In regards to the paper, it was clear that there was a lot of time spent on some periods than others, namely western theater, so it was easier to write about what we had spent the most time on. The exams to me felt like a crash course on memorization.

I support the idea of the paper, but find the format to have been an odd choice. While my schedule appreciated the fact that the paper was in the same format as the essays on the exams, I struggled seeing the point of the assignment considering it wasn't a full blown research paper with formatting and references required, and that the majority of the topics offered were things we had discussed in class therefore research was not required at all unless we picked the topics that had yet to be discussed in class.

The weekly discussion prompts were helpful in understanding the material and ensuring I was up to speed in the course. The essay was very similar in structure and objective to my previous schools, so I did not find them overly challenging or scary.
It's a lot of work but I don't see an inherent problem with that as expectations of that work was much more clearly defined than in other YSD courses I have experienced.
I don't know what the aims were, so I can't tell you. My experience, however, was....dry.
The work aligned well with the aims, but it felt like there was too much work in general.

I think that the tests are overly difficult for the aim of the course - to have an understanding of theatre history.  The tests are excessive.  What would be better would be weekly or bi-weekly quizzes with essays that cover those weeks' topics.
I would have preferred a more narrowed prompt for the essay assignment. The weekly discussion prompt were fairly straightforward.

I strongly disagree with the need to write a paper in this course. With the weekly discussions, readings, and short answers questions this course is already a heavy workload on the back of a drama student. With so much extra work, the students eventually stop actually reading the plays and have to opt for summaries or skimming. I think that does the subject matter a great disservice.
I liked the paper
n/a
NA

The weekly reading was not as bad as I thought it would be (as far as impacting my schedule goes), but the discussion questions were never brought up or responded to in group which made it incredibly hard to see the point. Often times the discussion group would focus on lectures rather than readings as well which meant that there were plenty of times in which it felt like we were reading plays just to read them but would never really talk about them.
The assigned reading was applicable to the weekly material, however it was a heavy load.
I thought the reading matched well with the weekly discussion. I loved my TA and any reserves I had about talking or asking questions were dispelled because of his generosity and kindness.

I would agree with a comment that was made on the last class day that when I could watch the video lectures earlier than the Tuesday of the standard lecture and in turn prior to reading the play I was more able to apply that knowledge to the reading. Which then made for a more engaging class with Paul on Thursday and discussion within the discussion group class.

There are a handful of plays that were just not going to make it onto my schedule to read, but I'm still glad they were assigned, and I learned as much about them as I could, and that seemed acceptable to me and to the discussions.
It didn't.
The assigned reading was acceptable, expect on weeks where something else was due, then it felt like too much. Those were the only weeks I didn't do the reading.
Pretty good, sometimes we did more reading than discussion could allow for.

The response topics for the next week's reading should be posted on Thursday, so that students have a full week to read and respond, not just how ever long the TA's give the student's by posting the topic at seemingly random times over the week.
I did my best to do the reading every week, but with some of the longer plays I would just do the minimum needed to answer the prompt.
Some of the plays were much easier to read. I found the plays written in more contemporary and conversational styles much more enjoyable to read
It was a lot with all other classes going on. Some weeks I had so much work with my production assignment that if I stayed up all night I still did not have time to do the readings.
I read about 60% and skimmed about 30%. Depending on other class work and production work it was difficult to find time to read.

I wish we didn't have to read so many plays.  and on the topic of the responses: toward the end of the semester, our group leader got better at posting the discussion topic early, but not so much in the beginning.  I wish they were always posted the weekend before.  It's so hard to finish the response during the week.
I found that it was helpful to discuss the readings on Tuesday rather than Thursday in that it provided context for what I would be reading/had already read.
I wonder if the discussion of this big plays will never be profound in this little amount of time?
I felt like I was constantly trying to keep up with the reading material
I wasn't able to read most of the assigned readings so I fell behind pretty quickly. The amount of readings required caused a lot of stress and anxiety.

At the start of the course when we had video lectures before class I was able to be more prepared. After that, I felt like I was floating most days, trying to catch what I could, but mostly feeling lost.

I absolutely appreciated and enjoyed the video lectures. Not only did it give me a chance to take thorough notes by pausing and / or rewinding the video numerous times, but it was great being able to decide when I was going to engage with those lectures --- what I mean is, I was able to watch the videos when I was more awake / alert and able to really focus on the information presented. Thanks to the lectures, I felt incredibly prepared for the midterm in regards to the Greek and Roman eras as we had numerous video lectures around those times. My notes were thorough and easy to study, but also having been able to take thorough notes meant I retained more from watching the lectures. Transitioning into live lectures where we have not had the video lectures has meant a drastic change in my notes and how much information I am actually retaining. In short, I do not feel prepared for the final in comparison to where I was with the midterm. 

At the beginning of the semester I thought having access to the power points would be helpful, but because of how they are used within the lectures they turned out to be the least helpful elements. The power points usually contained different information than what was being lectured on in that moment, used in the manner that would be best in an instructional video, and phased through too quickly to take notes on what was being presented or even read the slides. In many cases I had to force myself to ignore the slides in order to focus my energy on listening to the lecture and taking notes.

The video lectures were incredibly helpful. I benefited from being able to structure my Tuesday mornings in ways that would make me the most productive, being able to stop and start the lecture to go back and take notes at my own pace, and being able to go back and review them prior to the midterm exam. I distinctly felt their loss in the latter half of the semester and anticipate that I would have been able to prepare much better for the final had we still had the video lectures.

I think the films were very helpful in terms of going back and reviewing but I could not often tell what was important and what was not. I think the first couple weeks of class were stressful because I could not discern what was important based on the videos. 

But the videos are very helpful as supplements to the class lectures.
The videos were the same style of lecturing as the ones in class (difficult to follow and unengaging).
Loved the video lectures. Perfect way to conduct the class.
Video lectures allowed me to pause and work at my pace. The added videos of performance were great for context and a better understanding of the material.

The videos were GREAT.  It's wonderful to have a video guide to the lecture that I can pause and take notes, do additional research, and revisit.  The production value of the videos was GREAT.  I found a drastic different between my engagement in first half of year with videos and second half when they were no longer available. Three sessions a week is NOT sustainable in this YSD schedule.  It is just a completely unreasonable workload - and the value of the classes became ineffectual as productions picked up.  The video in lieu of one lecture allowed me to ingest on my own schedule, at my own pace.  It's more equitable for people who don't have a theater background (me).  I was able to pause and look up information that brought more meaning and value to the remainder of the video lecture - instead of being a bit lost throughout.

There is a lot more information in the slideshows than we are ever asked to retain on the tests. I have a hard time with that inconsistency. I spent a lot of time trying to remember all of the most important names during early French Baroque theater only to find that none of it was actually deemed "important".
As stated in multiple instances, the video lectures were helpful and made me better prepared for class when presented. I believe a visual medium helps better construction of engagement.
They didn't.
Keep those video lectures coming!
The videos were extremely helpful and Tuesday videos should be apart of the entire semester.
the videos were great.  make more of them.

Having the files to review really helped me study. The videos at the beginning of the semester were helpful in the sense that they let me watch at my own pace and when I could be most present. 9am most mornings I tend to still be pretty tired.
Videos were good. In the future if the class becomes just a Thursday lecture and Tuesday videos we can watch on our own time I think that would be great.

The video lectures were an incredible tool and fit perfectly along side in class lectures. They helped me to learn at my own pace.  It is the most accessible form of learning I've seen at Yale and could be improved by adding subtitles.
I would prefer there were more video lectures, the ability to pause, rewind and go back to certain things in the first few weeks of the semester was incredibly helpful.
The videos were good!

I loved the inclusion of video lectures, particularly ones that offered insight to the weekly reading. I found them insightful and helped me focus in on what was most thematically relevant in terms of the historical arch we were following.
Video lectures were incredible helpful in the first weeks, and also the access to class power points and lectures online.
It was helpful to have something I could pause, and go back and reference.
The videos weren't helpful for me because there were so many of them per week with so much information that it often took 3-4 times the amount of time to take notes as it would in class.
I honestly don't know what I learned this semester. A lot of the things I did "learn" I already knew from undergrad. Otherwise, I memorized a lot of things.

I truly appreciated the fact that this was the first theatre history course I have taken that did not present a white-washed history of performance, so it filled gaps by presenting performance history from regions outside of Europe and the US which was truly fascinating.
It is an incredible amount of content to master in a short time.
I have taken several theater history classes but this class was often more detailed.
Yes, though a little bittersweet in that the play selection seemed to have the same storyline throughout the different periods and regions.

Would be more effective to scale the numbers of tests so we had a bit more time to spend.  I found myself racing through material to keep up, so I'm not sure how much quality knowledge I've gained - more like hard and fast memorization or cramming.
I have a BA in Theater, so this was mostly review, except for the non-western topics.
I am a person who learns from inspiration, not by being talked at. I know some facts of it, but those aren't deeply important to myself or my story.
Filled in a lot, but honestly not sure how much I will retain.
It did what it set out to do.
I now have a better cursory knowledge of the history of theatre in certain areas.

I had done quite a bit of Theater History in undergrad. Since it had not been something I had dealt with often after leaving I had forgotten a lot of the details. I did not really find that this class filled gaps in my knowledge as much as reviewed things I had studied before.
I do not come from a theater background so much of the material was new for me and I liked it a lot.
This survey course chose some plays that I was not familiar with and opened the scope of work that I have previously considered. It helped to connect the dots of the development of theatre.

I feel like this course is too much a survey of so many different theatrical traditions for it to fill any gaps, there isn't the time or even effort made to delve in to each cultures traditions to the point where I feel confident speaking about a specific one.
yes. absolutely.
There is a lot of theater outside of Western norms that I wasn't familiar with, and I wish we had gone more in depth
The material went by so quickly without much repetition so I didn't feel like I was truly ever learning anything. I was just trying to get through the course and pass.
No.

I do not think you would be able to get many students within YSD to take it if it were not required because of the time commitment that comes with it (i.e. one week there were 7 videos, 2 plays, 1 lecture, 1 discussion question, and 1 discussion session -- aka 11+ hours of course related time for a single week). I would absolutely recommend it to people outside of YSD though.
Only if they were extraordinarily interested in the material.

I think I would tell every first year that it's essential to study theater history as part of being a storyteller. Even if the class was hard to follow at times due to it's pace, I thought it was for the most part followable. I gained a clearer timeline of socio-political events around the world and the artistic shifts that followed.
No. This course needs complete revamping. Please see below comments.
Depending on their interests.
I think everyone experiencing life can benefit from theatre history, so I would recommend this course.

I would. I think it's an incredible class.  Paul and the TAs are fantastic.  However, the intense workload makes it prohibitive and feel like academic hazing. Everybody *CRAMS* for exams.  Shoving trivial knowledge into their brain to regurgitate onto a paper for the exam then it's all a blur.  What's the value in that?  What's the value in assigning SO MUCH required reading.  It's not feasible in YSD... at least not for designers and TD&P.  Would've been great to explore the texts with the time for critical thinking and understanding.  Is the point of the class to produce a league of thoughtful, knowledgeable class of theater makers who engage with world history - OR is it academic hazing?

No, I think the "survey" nature of this class serves theater artists well, but would wash over anyone without a vested interest in theater practices, they would probably be happier in something a lot more focused.
No, never.
No. Sorry, but I don't think changing it will help.
If they wanted to know theatre history, yes. If not, no.
if they want a survey of theatre history, i can't think of one that is better.

I would recommend the course to someone if they showed any interest in the material. I felt it was an excellent class, however since it is not the focus of my studies in school it at times felt like more of a chore. The moments I was in class were fine but having to find time to do the readings and paper took some of the enjoyment out of it for me. If I had never taken a theater history course I think I would have enjoyed it more as well.
If theater history is of interest then this is a great class.
If they expressed a strong interest in theater history, then yes.
Yes.
I did not find this course particularly relevant to my degree program, it would depend on what that person is interested in. If it were not required I would be unlikely to take it.
Yes. I think it gives great context to a variety of mediums of art throughout history.

If you have a lot of time to really dive into the course, then YES absolutely.  But not if you don't have the time.  I almost wish Drama 6 was required in the 3rd year of TD&P... We just have more time, less homework and production assignments.

I think this course should continue to be necessary, particularly for writers/directors/designers. Arguably I am offering a biased opinion as an actor. While I found the course interesting, I could see this class being most beneficial to those in charge of shaping the worlds we are playing in.
Yes!
No.
No, I would not.
Yes
Yes.

The course goals were great, at the start of the semester we were asked what we wanted to gain from the course and it promised to teach us the history of theater. I feel like we did get to hear a lot about history of theater, but it was so compact, and so much information that I retained very little, and most of what I retained I had already learned in undergrad.
Yes, but sometimes I lost sight of them because it was hard to discern what was the most important part of lectures.
To my recollection...
If they were, I don't remember them, and I certainly did not accomplish them. Unless they were "pass this class"
Yes!
n/a
Paul Walsh definitely knows his stuff. My TA on the other hand seemed to know less than we did in my discussion group.

Paul's lectures are absolutely the most fascinating lectures to watch. He is incredibly knowledgeable on the topic of theatre history, but the amount of information and the speed in which it is presented makes it difficult to take adequate notes that lead to processing and learning enough to take things away from the course once completed.
He had an incredible grasp - it was just hard to follow and learn at the very fast pace of lectures.
Professor Walsh is extremely versed in the material. And even if the material was given to us a little too quickly, I felt Paul really cared about all of us enjoying the material.
It felt pretty cursory.
Seemingly yes, though I wish there was more time for discussion with Paul and not having that experience limited to the discussions with TA's/
Paul is great.

I would have learned more about the theatrical performances that werent Eurocentric and western based. I thought the knowledge for all subject were well informed, but I would have loved to learn more about the subjects that werent from the West little more in detail. It seemed as if we rushed certain aspects of Indian theatrical performance, compared to Holy theatre for example. It would also be nice to have a guest lecture discuss outside material away from the individual instructors knowledge.
I'm sure he does, but Paul lacked passion I know is there and I wish I could've seen it. He clearly knows his stuff, but the way that he relates it is so disconnected and uninspiring.
Paul seems to be the strong scholar in this field.
I wish he did not read so much during the lecture. He also mispronounced some of the Italian and German names.
Paul Walsh knows his shit.

It is abundantly clear to me that Paul is an incredibly intelligent person. I am sure that some of the multi-cultural theater inclusion is newer to this course and I wish that there was more sociopolitical discussion around non-eurocentric theater.
I don't question Paul's wealth of knowledge, and excitement he has about theater history, I just don't like his delivery of the material
n/a
The lectures felt really fast. It was a lot of information really fast.

Again, the video lectures were the best thing to happen to Drama 6. After the video lectures, the effective-ness of the lectures significantly reduced as we were now unable to pause Paul, rewind, etc. Taking effective notes became impossible.

Paul is brilliant and possesses expansive knowledge of the material. But the lecture were so verbatim and the slides would go so quickly that I sometimes felt he was more committed to getting all the information out in one hour rather than actually making sure we understood it.
No the lectures were disconnected and all over the place and dry.

The pace of lectures was difficult to follow. I understand why laptops are not allowed because most people would be doing other work but I would have liked to be able to scroll through the powerpoints during the lecture to write notes as I did while watching video lectures. The pace became too fast for me to follow which left me unengaged with the lessons.

See above comment.  TOO much information.  I was not able to truly present independent thinking or critical thought for the exams.  It felt like my peers and I crammed overnight to spew facts onto a page.  Disappointing.

No, the class moved far too fast and what Paul was saying rarely matched what was going on on the powerpoint and we were all too busy trying to scramble to information down to be able to process or listen or whatever it was we were supposed to do. This class asked us to do a lot and gave us no support in doing so. We weren't allowed to type, and he didn't move slowly enough for us to actually write things down, especially those with disabilities or language barriers.
Talked too fast, but other than, it was very clear the points he was trying to get across.
Paul needs to interact with the students more.
could slow down a little bit, but was great.

I could never tell what the important points were in each lecture. There was a lot of information and often times there was not emphasis on all of it. This in turn made note taking very difficult. I enjoyed the class more when I gave up on trying to take notes, but I am not sure how much information will actually be carried out of the class.
Some of the lectures were a little face paced and seemed rushed to cover all of the information.
The speed and shear volume of what was presented was unwieldy at times. over the course of the semester approximately 1000 powerpoint slides were displayed in class.
see above: "paul walsh knows his shit, AND is passionate about it!"

While I found the in class discussion to be fruitful, I wish that the power points were more congruent with what was being discussed. I often had an internal battle of what to be taking notes on due to the dual information being presented.
There's too much information to be discussed in a little amount of time. The instructor has to go so fast to cover all the material that the class becomes a fight for survival and passing.
I had a difficult time connecting with what Paul was saying. I'm a visual learner, and it was hard to keep up
Paul's style of teaching did not match with my style of learning so it left me feeling very overwhelmed, lost, and anxious.
Paul Walsh was definitely an advocate for trying his best to diversify the kinds of theaters we talked about and read about in the lectures.
There was not discussion - it was lecture.
We only spent one day on Indian history, one day on Japanese history and one day on Chinese history. I was shocked and saddened that we didn't give that material more time.
Not sure. Very little discussion time with Paul.
I'd say no since he never asked for our point of view, and when it did come up in small ways he was resistant. We never talked, just listened. There was little to no discussion in lecture time.
Great job of hearing other opinions.
yes?

The few times we did have time for questions Paul did an excellent job answering. In our group sections our TA did the same. In Lectures though there often was no time for questions or at least deep ones.
There wasn't a lot of room in the instruction for discussion of diverse points of view, but I guess that's what the small groups are for.
It is clear to me that Paul is making an effort to be more inclusive to different theatrical/cultural perspective.
n/a
Paul Walsh yes. My TA, no.
Paul was willing and able to answer questions presented to him during the last five or so minutes of lecture, but I found that questions were often unable to be answering during discussion sessions.

I felt like Paul didn't leave time for questions and when questions were asked he had a hard time going off script for them. I believe Paul really cared about his students but I often felt like I couldn't talk to him about the material. It would just be better to go to a TA.
Paul stuck mostly to his scripted lectures and saved little time for discussion.
When there was time.
I don't know because most of class time moved so fast that we didn't ask questions, there were some at the end that he answered but I'm not sure who they were pertinent to
I'm sure that he was willing, but he didn't know that there were questions because he spent more time in the slides than communicating with us.
yes?
When there was time.
There was so much information to cover there didn't always seem to be much time left for questions. However, the discussion groups were a good source to ask questions later.
absolutely
Always.
n/a
I understood the criteria.
I'm still not entirely sure what the point of the discussion questions is considering we never talk about them nor are we presented with grades or comments on our responses...
I thought the TAs helped illuminate that since they were the ones grading my material.
More so than most other YSD courses I have experienced.
Sure.

Never clear about my participation grade. 
Tests and paper were fairly clear.
no, it is a black box out of which the grades leap.

There was one discrepancy between the penalty for lateness on an assignment as presented in the syllabus and as presented when that assignment was distributed, it was rectified when brought to the instructors attention.
yes!
I never knew where I stood in regards to my participation grade
n/a
I never really sought consultation with Paul Walsh.

I am sure if I had asked, Paul would have been available to talk with us. He was very fun to have in our group during the one day where he led our discussion section. He was very amiable and eager to answer questions. But in a larger class, I didn't go to him with questions.
Don't know, never sought that resource.
Not that I know of, but I had very little interest in being consulted, discussed and advised so...
Seemed so, but never sought him out.
Paul made it very clear that he was always available as did his TAs
I sadly did not have the time to try and seek out help. Paul and the TA both seemed available if I ever needed to.
If you emailed him, he was there for you and would offer to meet 1 on 1.
I never really needed him, but Gavin was extra available.
n/a
Paul Walsh as a professor was very kind and well versed in theater knowledge. The 9am lectures weren't easy to grasp but he is definitely a great professor otherwise.
I would if the student had taken strongly academic, quick moving classes at their previous institutions.

This class needs a different kind of scholar. Someone who is going to give an updated, brazen, and rigorously researched takes on theatre history. Someone who can really perform and discuss unscripted to the class. If you're going to force us to take an academic class, please make it a great one. This is Yale. Find a young hip radical scholar that can give life-changing lectures. I wanted to be mind-blown by this material and there are professors who can do that. They are out there and looking for work.
Yeah, I'd still endorse this course despite my critiques.

This was a very strange shift to working with so many passionate teachers and then working with a teacher who seemed like he was fulfilling an academic agenda and staying on task as opposed to sharing his passion with theatre history. I can tell he loves history, just not when he's talking a mile a minute from a script that is different from the content on a projector that is also moving at a mile a minute and contains information that is complex but not unpacked, not analyzed, not compared to the place we take up in theatre today. This class seemed like a wasted opportunity for theatre and history enthusiasts. I wish we would've touched on the majesty of theatre history as opposed to just the facts and names and dates and movements. 

It just lacked imagination
Knowledgeable and passionate, if he taught something in your wheel house, he is a great instructor.
He knows his stuff.
if you want a smart theatre historian, Paul is your man.
YES

I attended all of them.
All of them
100% attendance.
11. Missed others due to time at Yale Health - which still counts as an absence and is a greater YSD problem.

I went to every class. I may have been a few minutes late on occasion.

All of them.
I stopped reading after the mid term because we never seemed to talk about them in the discussion group anyways and I had a lot of other things on my plate.

VIDEO LECTURES ARE AMAZING, PLEASE MAKE THIS A CONSTANT THING. With that let me add that if there is to be a live lecture as well, please consider modeling them after what was done for our first lecture meeting --- discussion, seminar style, with a little new information that ties the lessons of the video lecture together with a nice bow. I would also love to see the discussion group sessions be more structured and informative. This idea that we all get together and maybe discuss things according to what the students think of that day does not feel like the best use of time when we are all strapped for time to begin with. I hate saying it, but there were days in which discussion sessions felt like a waste of time in comparison to everything that needs to be done...

More video lectures and/or more written summary material of lectures. The live lectures move at an incredibly fast pace and can be difficult to follow. They also consist of a ton of information that has significant nuance and connections throughout. If there were more written materials summarizing the lectures that were available for review then it would be easier to go back and ruminate on the lectures later instead of trying to desperately keep up with notes.

I think the video lectures were helpful. I think Paul works really well in smaller groups with students but I had a hard time talking to him in class. Perhaps if he taught each discussion section once during the course of the semester?
I also would love to spend more time on non-Western theatrical history.

I am sorry to say it but this class is not rigorously taught. There is no thesis statement or original way of presenting the information in Paul's lectures. 
He reads pre-scripted lectures that have no real drive to main points but sound mostly like a wash of facts. His language is too wordy and inaccessible. 
The powerpoints didn't correspond to his written lectures making note-taking a frustrating task. I don't know why Paul expected the inclusion of paintings/scultptures of the time periods without much explanation to supplement explaining cultural/theatrical trends of the same periods. I have an art history degree and was shocked at how he included art historical references without diving into them and making valid connections with theatre of the moment. That's a whole separate course that needs unpacking if they're going to be at all useful.
Lecture style needs to be reimagined so that it can include pertinent information and leave room for relevant discussion.
I support the video Tuesday model because of the time it gave Paul to have Q&A time on Thursday and my ability to pause and engage with that material.

I tried in the beginning, I did. But I don't know why we have to take this course. I love history, like LOVE it, and this class seemed more like a report in which we were forced to offer our opinions. 

I want a practical use of the work. I feel as if we touched on it when discussing Shaminism, and then went write back to being talked at. 

Maybe it's the shortness of the semester versus the content of the class, but I felt like information was being shoved down my throat and I was expected to have an opinion on things that I couldn't relate to. There was no structure for discussion groups, all of us were just making enough comments to get points as opposed to having really interesting discussions about the work and how it reflects present day theatre. I would've loved to connect the past of theatre to the present or all that it's influenced in-between, but that is not what we did. I don't know what we did, I was just required to go.

Videos were great. 
Discussion was not even good. 
Slowing down would be helpful.

I think it's odd to police people's electronic devices. We should be treated like adults. I also think that it's odd to take points away if people don't speak in the lecture. There's not enough time for almost twenty people to say something thoughtful in a 50 minute lecture. Some of the rules were very childish and infantilizing.

I
Read
Every
Single
Play

My TA was not effective. He could not answer our questions and the discussion groups did not go very deep. Sometimes we sat in silence and he was late with grading. The actors in the class were the most comfortable talking and a couple of them took over the class and made it hard for others to speak.

More videos. (Add subtitles and limit length to duration of a class period)
Better canvas organization.

the 7 pm cut off on Wednesday for on line responses was tight for TD&P students who are often on the clock every day until 6 pm or later, workable but at times forced a late submission because of the seemingly arbitrary time constraint.
NO PAPER PLEASE!

I wish I knew how to take notes for this class.  I also wish Paul would upload his CURRENT presentation into canvas before the class.  It would be nice to print off the current presentation and follow along taking notes on it. Often, the presentation I printed off wasn't current.  If he would do this, I would love it if he would upload it the Sunday or Monday before the classes that week.
I feel like I said what I needed to say in the hand-written evaluations
The discussion sessions were really not useful. If anything I ended up feeling more lost some days.
The only reason I am not rating this as a 1 is because I see the potential of the discussion sections, but as previously stated I believe they need more structure and a more defined purpose / goal.
The discussion section was my favorite aspect of the class - I do not do well in pure lecture settings.
I loved my TA! He made the discussion sections fun and illuminating. I felt ready for the tests and the essay thanks to his help.

There need to be more specific goals for these discussions because in Ilyas section we did not talk about the subject matter at all but were stalled out in repeating over and over and over and over basic expectations of what a paper is, what an exam is, where the exam is, when the exam is, who is writing the exam, when they are writing the exam, etc. Just really basic, irrelevant questions became the entire discussion so that we never actually discussed the actual subject matter.
Fantastic.
Helped for test preparation. Days were the response structure wasn't open to all was better as myself and seemingly others don't jump in if people are actively taking up the conversation space.

The discussion sections privileged students who are more talkative or more energetic in the morning over students who are more reserved in large groups, and did so by rewarding more points to the loudest students. I had a hard time feeling successful or engaging honestly because I was too worried about trying to say anything at all so as to not lose points for the day. I think that it is unfair to try to judge anyone by anything other than attendance, and I think that engaging in the subject matter should just be a given after that. This is a graduate level program, I don't think I need to extra incentive to speak, especially when it ends up causing me stress and shutting me down.

I truly can't tell you what we discussed, what was clarified. It seemed like an hour-long quiz. I don't know what purpose it served. 

Discussions felt very much like wasted time, except before exams in which they were a cram session. If we are expected to write papers and have discussions and read and listen, I feel excitement should come in somewhere. There was no passion in this work, there was no indication that everyone loved what they were doing and that was really sad to experience every Tuesday and Thursday morning.
My TA poorly managed the class, did not have a plan or outline for the discussion. Not useful.
did not further the goal of understanding the material.
The Lectures were very important but I found I enjoyed the discussion sections more. It is hard to say if that would have been as effective without the lectures.
I felt that I had the best discussion leader and he made retaining the information so much easier.
My TA was very bad (see explanation above).
It was poorly organized and needed structure.

I wish the small groups prepped us more for the exam.  It was hit or miss.  Sometimes the instructor would really prep us, and sometimes we would talk about the play alone.  I wish there was more context.
Maria was a fantastic TA. Incredibly articulate while also maintaining a fun-loving vibe.
Could be better in terms of highlighting the most important key points to discuss in every section.
I was able to retain more information, and have more clarification, from the discussion groups, than I was from most lectures.
Discussion groups were the best part of the course.
I felt like we would wonder a lot and not stick to the topics at hand.
I would have liked more discussion because I got more out of it, but I don't think that total weekly class time should be longer.
I think an hour a week was an appropriate amount of time.
Yep.
pass
I felt the discussion questions for the TA sessions could have been more structured, and engaged with more questions about the reading than asking the what ifs of the subject matter.
Too much time as, again, I don't know what they were for.
Since they were useless, too much?
yes.

I wish there had been more discussion section time. That being said I also am not sure if I would have done as much personal studying outside of lectures to make the discussion sections worthwhile if lectures went away.
In order to have an excellent discussion is required more time.
I would've preferred more time in discussion and less time on the lectures.
Discussion sessions dont seem to be crucial to full fit my expectations for this class
